title: Erdős Problem #889: New Prime Factors in Consecutive Integers
description: Let v(n,k) count prime factors of n+k not dividing n+i for i < k. Does v₀(n) = max_k v(n,k) → ∞ as n → ∞? Known: v₀(n) ≥ 2 for n ≥ 17. OPEN.

overview.historicalContext: Erdős and Selfridge (1967) studied the prime factors of consecutive integers n, n+1, ..., n+k. They defined v(n,k) as the count of prime factors of n+k that are 'new' (don't divide any earlier term). They proved v₀(n) ≥ 2 for n ≥ 17, with exceptions at n = 0,1,2,3,4,7,8,16, but could not establish divergence. The problem also appears as B27 in Guy's collection.
overview.problemStatement: Let v(n,k) count the prime factors of n+k that do not divide n+i for 0 ≤ i < k. Let v₀(n) = max_{k ≥ 0} v(n,k). Does v₀(n) → ∞ as n → ∞?
overview.proofStrategy: We define newPrimeFactorCount (v(n,k)) using Finset filtering on primeFactors, then v₀ as the supremum. ErdosProblem889 states divergence. Known results (v₀(n) ≥ 2 for n ≥ 17, exception list) are axiomatized. The generalized v_l and the exact power variant V(n,k) are also formalized.
keyInsights: v(n,k) counts prime factors of n+k not dividing any of n, n+1, ..., n+k-1
The generalized v_l(n) restricts the supremum to shifts k ≥ l
The exact power variant V(n,k) uses p^α divisibility instead of p divisibility

sections.title: New Prime Factor Count
sections.summary: Defines newPrimeFactorCount v(n,k): prime factors of n+k not dividing any n+i for i < k.

sections.title: The Maximum v₀
sections.summary: Defines v₀(n) as the supremum of v(n,k) over all k.

sections.title: Known Results
sections.summary: Axiomatizes v₀(n) ≥ 2 for n ≥ 17 and the complete exception list {0,1,2,3,4,7,8,16}.

sections.title: Generalized Version v_l
sections.summary: Defines vShifted (v_l) and the generalized conjecture: v_l(n) → ∞ for every fixed l.

sections.title: Finiteness of v₁(n) = 1
sections.summary: The question of whether v₁(n) = 1 has only finitely many solutions.

sections.title: Exact Power Variant V(n,k)
sections.summary: Defines exactPowerNewCount V(n,k) using p^α divisibility, exactPowerShifted V_l, and the comparison V ≥ v.

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem 889 asks whether the maximum count of new prime factors in consecutive integers diverges. Erdős and Selfridge proved v₀(n) ≥ 2 for n ≥ 17 but could not show divergence. The problem remains open.
conclusion.implications: Resolution would reveal fundamental growth properties of prime factor distributions in consecutive integer sequences.
openQuestions: Does v_l(n) → ∞ for every fixed l?
Does v₁(n) = 1 have only finitely many solutions?
